title: How to Conquer Your Paper Piles

steps.headline: Arrange one large sorting area.
steps.description: It could be your desk, though you might have to remove everything from its surface. It could also be your bed or dinner table, or even the kitchen counters if they are clean.

steps.headline: Put all the paper in one place.
steps.description: If you are sure the piles are already sorted, you can keep them separate. Otherwise don't bother and put them all in one big pile.

steps.headline: Take one paper after the other, breathe deeply and remind yourself to relax if you get tense or anxious.
steps.description: Decide if it requires action, has to be filed or can be thrown away.

steps.headline: If it can be trashed, create a trash pile or bin and add other papers to it as they come along.
If it requires action, put it in an action pile and stick a post-it on it with the required action or any prerequisite steps.
If it should be filed, file it, unless there's no folder that has this category in it yet.
steps.description: In that case, choose a category for the paper, write it on a post-it and put both on your sorting surface.

steps.headline: Add papers to the existing piles.
steps.description: When you have sorted everything, have a look at the piles that are too big to go into one folder. Can you break them up into sub-categories?

steps.headline: Check if your filing system is still up-to-date.
steps.description: Think about retrieval. What will you be looking for and where? Is it all in a sensible place? Don't skimp on folders and indices. Buy new ones if necessary. It's too frustrating to look for the "car"-files in all folders because you can't remember where you added it to.

steps.headline: Create Folders for the categories that are still missing from your system.
Create a system to tackle new incoming paper.
